title: 2025 Government Shutdown Impact Analysis
detail: Explore the cascading effects across economy, society, and politics

children.title: Economic Impact
children.detail: GDP losses, contractor effects, and market disruption

children.title: Economic Loss
children.detail: Each week of shutdown costs $7-15B GDP

data.content: The 2025 shutdown halts ~6% of discretionary federal spending, creating ripple effects throughout the economy. Each week costs approximately $7-15 billion in GDP loss, with $50B+ if exceeding 4 weeks.

children.title: GDP Breakdown
children.detail: Discretionary spending represents 5-6% of GDP, creating ripple effects throughout the economy.

children.title: Consumer Confidence
children.detail: CCI dropped from 97.8 (Aug) to 94.2 (Sept), with 92 estimated for Oct. Low consumer confidence leads families and businesses to postpone major spending decisions.

children.title: Negotiation Timeline
children.detail: Complete chronology of shutdown events

events.label: Sep 19, 2025
events.note: The House passes a short-term Continuing Resolution (CR) aimed at averting a government shutdown. The Senate does not take up the measure amid ongoing partisan divisions over spending priorities.

events.label: Sep 30, 2025
events.note: The Senate fails to advance both Democratic and Republican funding proposals, setting the stage for a lapse in federal funding at midnight.

events.label: Oct 1, 2025
events.note: Federal funding expires at 12:01 a.m. EDT, triggering a partial government shutdown. Approximately 900,000 employees are furloughed, and about 700,000 continue working without pay.

events.label: Oct 1, 2025
events.note: Senate leaders hold preliminary discussions on a shorter-term funding extension described as 'productive,' though no agreement is reached.

events.label: Oct 1, 2025
events.note: Financial markets show mixed reactions to the shutdown. Stock futures fluctuate and gold prices reach record levels as investors weigh potential economic impacts.

events.label: Oct 1, 2025
events.note: The administration announces a temporary freeze of approximately $26 billion in previously approved federal funds, including allocations for transit and clean-energy projects in several states, pending budget resolution.

events.label: Oct 2, 2025
events.note: The Senate again fails to pass funding legislation. The partial government shutdown continues with no bipartisan deal in place.

events.label: Oct 2, 2025
events.note: Department of Education employees report that automated out-of-office messages were modified to include political statements. The department initiates an internal review.

events.label: Oct 3, 2025
events.note: Speaker Mike Johnson extends the House recess into the following week as negotiations between congressional leaders remain at an impasse.

events.label: Oct 5, 2025
events.note: The federal government remains partially closed for a fifth day. Agencies continue limited operations while essential services remain active.

events.label: Oct 6, 2025
events.note: The Senate fails to advance another stopgap funding bill requiring 60 votes. The President and White House renew calls for a bipartisan agreement to restore federal operations.
